page.title: 04TOURISM in Blindcrake
page.content: Although off the beaten track, there are many visitors to the area to see both the village and the geological outcrops, (Blindcrake's ancient name was "top rock"). 1985 has been one of the wettest and coldest summers this century but the two caravan sites attract people as the outer fringes of the Lake District National Park grows in popularity. Annual visitors are the gypsies with their horse drawn caravans who camp on the Ghyll Yeat pub field (opposite the pub) on their way home from Appleby Fair. The pub has only one small room! Walks to Clints Crags and Sunderland returning via Isel are becoming very popular for both visitors and locals. There is no hotel or bed and break- fast accomodation in the village but there is a motel at Moota on the main Carlisle to Cockermouth road.
